Award.AwardTitle: Are stellar halos the leftovers from galactic cannibalism?
Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to clarify the assembly histories of galaxies, focusing in particular on their stellar halos. In the current conceptual picture of structure formation in the early universe, small gravitationally bound systems dominate in number, and the present population of galaxies is formed by multiple mergers of these protogalactic objects. Cosmological simulations predict that the extended stellar components of galaxies are built up by the merging and tidal disruption of dwarf galaxies. Since orbital times are long in these regions, a memory of this accretion should persist in the form of coherent structures in space and/or velocity. The Principal Investigator and collaborators have identified and quantified these structures in the halo of the Milky Way. In this project they will carry out an observational program on the 6.5-meter Magellan telescope to map the faint, extended stellar halos in 4 nearby spiral galaxies, tripling the number of galaxies mapped to this depth. Using N-body simulations of dwarf galaxy accretion, they will develop quantitative measures of halo structure that are effective indicators of the accretion history. They will then apply the new metrics both to their new observations of external galaxies and to large-scale survey data on the halo of the Milky Way from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and from the Pan-STARRS 1 survey. The goal is to sensitively test theories of stellar halo formation. The project will involve the professional training and mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher and undergraduate students. The Principal Investigator will also participate in outreach through visits to elementary school classrooms and a coordinated effort to improve the astronomical content of the on-line reference Wikipedia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our current understanding of the Universe includes as a central component 'dark matter', whose presence one infers from detecting the gravity from more mass than one can see on galactic scales.  Dark matter does not interact at all (or at the very least, undetectably often) with electromagnetic radiation (light, radio waves, gamma rays, etc); therefore, our main handle on how it acts is by exploring the distribution and behavior of matter on galactic scales.  Galaxies are predicted to assemble in great part from the merging of smaller dark matter rich sub-units, and such mergers are expected -- for galaxies like the Milky Way -- to result in diffuse (and richly-structured) envelopes of stars around the main bodies of spiral galaxies like the Milky Way. These diffuse envelopes of stars are called 'stellar halos', and are expected to be gold mines of information for discovering how galaxies form, on a galaxy-by-galaxy basis.

The primary intellectual merit of NSF-AST 1008342 was to observationally measure the structure of the stellar halos of our Galaxy and a few nearby galaxies, and connect those measurements with realistic computer simulations of how stellar halos form. A major highlight of this project is our mapping, with unprecedented accuracy, of the transition region between the outer disk of our galaxy and the stellar halo. The outer disk transitions into an enormous ring around the galaxy, reaching heights more than 10,000 light years below and above the disk. This ring appears to be most likely the disk of the Milky Way, disrupted by interactions with satellite galaxies. This offers decisive and crucial insight into how galactic disks survive and grow - it offers a picture of disk disruption as it's happening. Other works quantify the structure of the Galaxy's and a nearby galaxy's (NGC 253) stellar halos.

A second important highlight was a careful study of systematic error in current simulations of stellar halo formation. We found that a number of the leading models of stellar halo formation -- by neglecting the gravity from the main disk of the galaxy in shaping the disrupting satellite galaxies that form the stellar halo -- incorrectly predict the shape of stellar halos. This was an important realization, and charts the path for improving the next generation of halo simualtions.

The kind of observational data used to study the diffuse stellar envelopes for galaxies are also fruitful for discovering and characterizing faint satellite galaxies around these galaxies. These galaxies -- as the faintest and most diffuse collections of stars ever discovered -- offer critical insight into how stars form in concentrations of dark matter. In NSF-AST 1008342, we discovered of contributed to the discovery of five new dwarf satellites of the nearby Andromeda galaxy, most at distances in excess of 150kpc from M31, and six Milky Way companions (a mix of galaxies and globular clusters). Furthermore, we systematically studied what processes influence the gas content of these small dwarf galaxies, finding that proximity to large galaxies like the Milky Way or Andromeda strips the dwarf galaxies of their gas content, leaving just the stars behind.

Introductory astronomy courses attract students from a wide range of backgrounds, and Michigan has the largest enrollment in face-to-face classes in the nation (>2500/year). The primary broader impacts of NSF-AST 1008342 were the development and systematic assessment of improved 'active learning' activities for students in such classes, where students are invited to take more of a role in creating their knowledge, leading (in ideal cases) to improved long term learning and motivation. Activities were developed, and assessments of student learning developed and applied across a wide range of introductory astronomy classes.
